About time:
2006	9 October: North Korea announces that it has performed its first-ever nuclear weapon test. 
2009	25 May: North Korea tests its second nuclear device.
2013	12 February: North Korea tests its third nuclear device.
Source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_the_North_Korean_nuclear_program

1) Songun Chongch'i [Army First] policy: http://www.globalsecurity.org/military/world/dprk/songun-chongchi.htm
2) Technically, a state of war exists between the UN and DPRK.
3) USA main enemy, with the total belief that it is out to destroy them (their view): https://www.washingtonpost.com/opinions/increasing-sanctions-is-just-one-part-of-the-north-korean-puzzle/2015/12/25/6b8ff572-a
http://www.koreaherald.com/view.php?ud=20151226000021
4) Nuclear weapons and related delivery systems are key to their survival (their view).
5) You have it, you test it. Make sure your design works (there were questions about the success of the 3 prior tests). One of the main reasons why they won't sign this: Comprehensive Nuclear Test-Ban Treaty (CTBT): http://www.state.gov/t/avc/c42328.htm
(USA has perfected it's weapons, conducted 1,030 tests and deployments (Nagasaki and Hiroshima) since 1945).
6) USA has superior nuclear war-fighting capability (see point number 4): 'Strategic Triad': http://sdc-usa.org/the-us-nuclear-triad/

North Korea has begun digging a tunnel for a nuclear test site.   Secretary Ashton Carter recently (Sunday) visited South Korea to discuss the North Korea's missile and nuclear threat.  Three previous tests have been held on the east coast of North Korea.  Sources indicate that active vehicles and workers are the site where the tunnel is being constructed.  Construction indicates a clear intent on the part of North Korea to test (a) nuclear device.

Many people posing the baseline of a new nuclear test every 3 years, yet:
1- nuclear testing worldwide seems more correlated to trying new warhead designs (and are only secondarily to power posturing). How much a relatively mature nuclear power needs, desires, and can afford new warheads every 3 years is questionable.
2. Increasingly testing can be replaced by computer modeling and simulation, although admittedly this is still imperfect, NK increasingly may have the programming capacity. Testing/modelling can also be replaced by industrial stealing/trade of proven designs.
3. Ongoing talks, needs for investment, opening of FTZs, a more open society, pressure from neighbor China, signs of willingness to negotiate nuclear issues, etc., decrease chances in this question for the next 12 months, relative to the missile question because there there is uncertainty generated because NK can somewhat claim the right to a space program.
Btw, 70% chance on a Ban Ki Moon visit to NK before the end of the year.
Whenever things go wrong in North Korea , Kim Jong Un looks for a big distraction. A nuclear test seems to soothe his psyche.
If the SLBM test was a failure, I'd expect some successful demonstration sooner rather than later. (no change)

The metaphor is imperfect, but it's not crazy to think of the DPRK as a mildly spoiled 12-year-old boy.  Instead of asking what the third-generation leader of a very repressive and generally isolated country might do, ask what your nephew--the one you don't like very much--might do.  (I am hampered in this exercise by a relative paucity of nephews, and I like them, but models are not rare elsewhere.)
Iran deal holds, pressure from Iran and China keeps North Korea status quo until new 6 party talks. Then again, NK has nothing to lose.
Have looked to be gearing up for a while, according to South Korea's Intelligence Agency. Whether it will be a successful test is debatable as it doesn't seem to be the only purpose of the test.

Reasons for North Korea to conduct a nuclear test:
- North Korea appears to have launched again its main nuclear facility Yongbyon, and is digging a new tunnel at its nuke test site; furthermore, it's latest test is from 2013 - more than 3 years ago
- Could get some support from China, it's closest ally, as it moves attention away from other potential sources of conflict (e.g. SE-Asia artificial islands)
- A nuclear weapon would make NK almost untouchable from a military point of view
- Being a nuclear power provide some attention and leverage in the international arena, either for NK or even China, and specially within staggering negotiations for de-nuclearisation of NK
- Demonstrates that nuclear weapons exist, or at least are closer to exist

North Korea won't test further nuclear weapons unless there is a perceived threat from the outside, such as being called a rogue nation in the context of one of these other labelled rogue nations being invaded. The Invasion of Iraq was 2003, and the first of a sequence of nuclear tests on the part of North Korea started in 2006. It's unlikely that a nation outside the West would threaten North Korea, and the current U.S. administration seems more measured in their language and their actions than the last. The biggest risk of further nuclear tensions would be the South China Sea flashpoint between China, the West and Western allies in the region.

Started with a base rate dependent on historical averages. Analysis of current enrichment program is spotty - no adjustment made. But time between tests seems to be a big factor; increased forecast. Then a smaller discount as all of this has only happened in the past 10 yrs - don't want to put too much emphasis on the near past.

timing is about right for preparing another small test.  likely the quantity for an ICBM.

This forecast corrects my earlier mistake of misreading the year in the question. Before January 1 2017, I see two ways that a nuclear test could come about: I project 25% odds that the core messaging around the KWP congress will be aggressive and that a nuclear test will be part of that messaging. I project 20% odds that the test will be carried out for some other reason. If NK propaganda leading up to the KWP congress is especially belligerent, I'll increase my forecast. If we get to the end of the KWP congress and there is no test, I'll reduce my forecast.
It doesn't seem to happen very often and they're starving to death. Russia is also strained on resources, so is not a reliable ally.

That time frame may be sufficient to enrich enough material for another detonation but the likelihood still remains low.

North Korea conducted its nuclear test about every 3 years (37 months), indicating the development cycle is less than 3 years. Since the last nuclear test was in February 2013, it is possible to have another test before Jan 2017. In July 2015, Ji Jae Ryong, North Korea’s ambassador to China, said the Iran deal is irrelevant because the North is already “a nuclear weapons state both in name and in reality.” “We are not interested at all in dialogue to discuss the issue of freezing or dismantling our nukes unilaterally first,” he said at the North Korean Embassy in Beijing. Since then, satellite image showed active activity at Punggye-ri nuclear test site. North Korea also reportedly digging a new tunnel at Punggye-ri to prepare for more tests.

The threat of conducting a nuclear test is more valuable than actually carry out the test itself. Once they cross the line they cannot get any concessions. The caveat though is that Kim could conduct a test if he feels any internal threats to his hold on power is significant enough for him to have to show what he is prepared to do.

Its latest test was in February 2013 and involved what it claimed was a "miniaturised" nuclear device, though experts say it is impossible to confirm if this is true.

There seems little reason why conducting a nuclear test would advance the cause of North Korea, especially considering the current geopolitical situation involving refugees and ISIS. North Korea will attract little international attention, and a nuclear test would merely aggravate tensions with the West. However, the leadership does not always act in a rational way. North Korea hasnt been in the spotlight lately and with thier recent aniversary will seek to improve relevance in global community.

Tough one, but I think it will happen.  The PRC will not want this, as they have plenty on their plate as it is. The DPRK can't afford to make China too nervous, but always want to show they're independent in at least a few ways as long as Mom & Dad don't cut off their allowance or ground them. betting prc keeping nk on a tight leash.

Base rate: Given the historical frequency, a test seems to be an unlikely event every given year (average about 0.33 a year, 0.37 until 1/1/2017).
Inside view: The North Korean regime is largely a black box, so there is little sense in speculating what would it do... but nevermind that. Nuclear test demonstrates nuclear capability, which serves as a deterent. Additional tests have diminishing returns, because threat credibility has been already establised (including 2013 test under Kim Jong-un's leadership). Diplomatic costs are high (also diminishing?). Test is a bad idea, say only 0.33 of the base rate, ie 0.12 in total.
The next one probably won't be used for a test. Although there maybe many more missile delivery system tests.
It seems that everything in North Korea occurs on the wim of Kim: for domestic political reasons, to impress the international community, or in conjunction with a special holiday
How many angels can dance on the head of a pin?

No, because North Korea recently announced that  is trying to create a peace treaty with South Korea. Along with this, it is having problems with China after it threatened its neighbor to the north with troop movements to the border. North Korea just went through a drought and the creation of a partial free market farming industry. It is actually necessary for North Korea to avoid nuclear testing in order that it can create a more productive diplomatic relationship with its neighbors.

Unlikely, with the President of China's recent remarks about settling the South China Sea issue peacefully, I doubt North Korea wants to piss off China by giving the U.S and its allies a greater excuse to militarize the region. We are much more likely to see a new missile test than a nuclear one.

I think they are more focused on demonstrating a successful long-range missile test. That would probably cause more worldwide consternation than a nuclear test. So, their engineering/science resources are probably directed to the missile test(s).

Given the time frame I'm going to start my forecast a little higher than many. What makes NK hard to forecast is that they can be very unpredictable. Most recently, one of Kim's closest advisors, Choe Ryong-Hae appears to be no longer among the favored after being "removed" from a high ranking post. If Kim feels ignored or slighted he might rattle his saber, bluster about US hegemony, or threaten war with the South. I suspect as our presidential elections get closer he may to draw attention to North Korea, either by a missile or nuclear test. Of course, they may do these things "just because."

initial forecast. Not a lot of recent activity noted, but it would be expected that one would likely be conducted in this timeframe.  As @ravel noted below, the KN-08 is under active development, and miniaturization of a warhead is necessary given payload constraints.
It's about that time for them to make news (I remember from GJP it was about every 3ish years). Given long time period of question, going to start with moderate yes.
Taking into account the rate of past tests and need to be noticed in the world arena the likely hood is high.

As per http://www.cnn.com/2013/10/29/world/asia/north-korea-nuclear-timeline---fast-facts/index.html the last 3 nuclear tests completed by North Korea have been October 2006, May 2009 and February 2013.  There have been 31 and 45 months between the last 2 tests.  The predicted date range of the next test is September 2015 to November 2016.
NK has pattern of nuclear test every 3-4 yrs. January 2017 falls in this range.
Increasing connectivity to the outside world will sway government sentiment to participate in peaceful global actions.

North Korea has conducted 3 nuclear tests since 2006 ~ roughly 30%  of the years.  With roughly 1.1 years until the deadline I'll establish a base rate of 33% = (30% x 1.1).  Reports from South Korea intelligence suggest NK is preparing for another test, so I'll adjust up to 36%.
North Korea might choose to do this just for the publicity.
I think it is even odds, here, given that North Korea might do this just for attention.

Based on the history of nuclear testing in Korea, I do no expect to see another test until at least mid 2017 or 2018.  It appears that each successive test has increased the yield compared to the previous test by almost 100%.  Assuming that nuclear development is underway, the next atomic test will be at least 12-15 kt. This will require approximately 1 pound of enriched U-235 - which involves hundreds if not thousands of gas centrifuges spinning down uranium hexafluoride.
There will be a lot of tough talk during the U.S. election season. but Korea is certain that nothing would impede their testing before 1/1/17
3 tests in the last 10 years but most recent was 2013.

Agree with cdob63 that the long time frame almost guarantees a test. Of course there could be a regime change, a deal to denuclearize the peninsula, or some other black swan, but I'll go with routine program and political factors to forecast high.

Sometimes the DPRK tests things to see whether they work, or how to improve them. Sometimes the DPRK tests things just to get attention.  In there somewhere is pretty good odds of a test within the time frame of this question.

While technical improvements and objectives are obviously important to those tasked with developing the North Korean nuclear program, these tests are primarily political. Does the regime seek attention or have a larger goal with which to leverage the threat or reality of a test? Winter is coming and it is almost always stressful on the North Korean economy and food distribution system. Depending on the state of the harvests and the forecasts for winter, a test might be seen as a way to get needed aid. Conversely a test may be seen as too much of a threat to such assistance, especially from their Chinese neighbors. It also may be seen as useful in solidifying the regime domestically. There are a lot of angles on this issue and thus it is a tossup.

Probable! North Korean regime doesn't believe in sharing information nor do they offer insights into their country, we have to seek help from their closest ally China that opposes their nuclear program, not much help but only source of information.
